text:
Mine was a little different, but my hubby and I launched our agency because I had more freelance work than I could handle and we identified a recurring problem that we knew we could solve.

After about a year and a half, I stopped working at my 30 hour/week contract job and went full time with the agency. I'm decent at sales, for the most part, but definitely have had to pick up tasks and areas that weren't my forte. 

It's a very rewarding process, if you are built for it. But it's also very up and down getting started. Like startups, new agencies tend to be feast or famine for awhile. It's super stressful, especially balancing hiring vs. being conservative with client money and investing in growth.

If I had it to do over again, I would. But I also would have started therapy right away instead of waiting :sweat_smile:

text:
I did this last year. I was writing 8-10 long form pieces per month and realized to do more, I’d have to either hire people or work more hours.

So, I started hiring:
• First I subcontracted to a couple friends who I could trust.
• Next, I found an editor (because I’m not a good editor) to help on a freelance basis
Paying a few freelancers is actually pretty easy. You can use PayPal and they’ll handle the tax paperwork for you (but obviously they take fees).

For a while, I used Quickbooks, which was okay. They also handle 1099s so that made it easy, but it didn’t scale.

Now we have over 100 freelance writers, so we use a specialized platform called <http://Pilot.co|Pilot.co>, which is pretty nice.

-----

The only other advice I’ll add is to get out of execution (writing, editing, etc.) as quickly as possible. Yes, quality may suffer, but it’s the only way you can spend enough time on sales/marketing. From the beginning, I committed to spend at least 50% of my time on growth.

Good luck!

text:
TL;DR: How do you manage the leap from small, scrappy agency-of-freelancers to a more mature, growth-oriented agency?

The editorial agency where I'm one of four partners was founded in 1993, by a solo freelancer who had too much work to handle himself. The early model was based on keeping overhead as low as possible. Writers/reporters were paid hourly -- so those costs could expand and contract along with the volume of work. Fast forward to today: The founder, who is still the majority owner, is largely retired and the three partners in my generation (mid to late 40s) are now running the company along with two other senior folks. We have grown -- and professionalized our operations -- substantially over the years, but we hang onto some of the practices (and mindset) from the company's origins, and we're starting to wonder if they're impeding our growth.

To wit:  We still pay everyone -- including ourselves -- hourly. We have literally never "hired" someone for a full-time "job" -- we typically try people out and develop them slowly over time.

The challenge: Our senior team is maxed out, and we need to bring in someone(s) else at our level - mid- to later career, with great editorial & client management skills. The more we think about this, it seems unlikely that such a person would be willing to make this commitment w/o the offer of a full-time job with standardized benefits. At the same time, committing to that fixed cost would be an enormous shift from how the company has been run for the last 25+ years.

I realize this is a very specific problem, but I'm wondering if any of you have faced similar hurdles as your agency has grown. If so, how did you think through the risks and the opportunities? Any advice to offer?

text:
"The more we think about this, it seems unlikely that such a person would be willing to make this commitment w/o the offer of a full-time job with standardized benefits."

I'm calling this out because it sounds like you are making some assumptions that might not be based in reality. You and your partners seem to have thrived and accepted the current structure, so what is to stop a new peer from doing the same? With all of the talent leaving full time (especially in-office) positions in favour of more flexibility, you might find that loads of people would appreciate the kind of opportunity you're talking about.

My advice is to frame your circumstance as a feature rather than a bug and find someone who, like your partners, is entrepreneurial enough to buy into the way you do things now.

text: Thanks, <@U02DRCPMH47>. I should have noted - none of us started out in these roles. We grew into them very slowly over time. I started freelancing for the company in 2006. Made it my FT gig a few years later; didn't become a partner until 2014. (Also, fwiw, sometimes we really wish we were salaried, too.)

text:
We do pretty much everything, though it varies by client -- some clients have deep expertise of a niche area, so they provide the content and we do the keyword research, outline, editing, etc. Clients approve nearly everything that goes out. We're split into two marketing teams, each handling half our clients, and I'm on both teams (as the only content person). I'm thinking having a content marketer on each team would be a good first step, giving them the bulk of execution, freeing me up to do more strategic, big picture thinking, and general management. Beyond that it's hard to say, but I am not sure if I need a solid plan beyond that bc things change with our team structure fairly regularly around here.

Overall I'm just having difficulty organizing my head around how to scale my efforts with minimal help -- I can hire freelancers but we tend to go into periods where we want to limit cost on contractors, so that always throws a wrench into things. And I won't be able to hire anyone for at least 6 months. Ultimately I kinda feel like I'm in a hole as a team of one managing so many clients, where I'm just in short-term execution mode most of the time, and I'm not really sure how to start pulling myself out of the hole to get things on more of a long term schedule.

text: I hear you. I guess I want to believe that you can find the person you're looking for. It sounds like a great opportunity for the right person.

elements.text: I hear you. I guess I want to believe that you can find the person you're looking for. It sounds like a great opportunity for the right person.

text:
Thank you Karl! I'm about at that point of, "well, I can only do more if other people do it." Good to know so many of you transitioned in a "soft launch" way that involved informal freelancers and incremental growth. That is more appealing to me than hanging up a shingle and trying to be something I am not.
I guess I better sign up for therapy and just wade in. :joy:

text: Therapy, having a mastermind group of other small business owners, and having a supportive spouse were key for me. :grin:

elements.text: Therapy, having a mastermind group of other small business owners, and having a supportive spouse were key for me.
